The Heritrix jar must be first on the CLASSPATH.  It provides alternate 
implementations of a few of the httpclient classes.

Also, regards embedding, I'd suggest that if possible, you should try to 
not be so intimately involved with Heritrix.  These internal APIs are 
likely to change making your embedding of Heritrix brittle.  The direct 
creation of CrawlJobHandler with calls to #getJob is how our Danish 
compaï¿½eros embed the crawler.  They did it this way because at the time 
there was no other means available to them.

Since then we've added a public 'remote control' API available via JMX. 
I'd suggest you use the API since it is more immune to change (Least, 
we'll be more careful making changes on this interface.  Services 
running here at the Archive depend on it being constant so we're even 
less likely to change it).

If there is JMX Agent running in the current JVM, any created Heritrix 
instance will register itself there.  Thereafter you can go via the JMX 
Agent to add jobs, get status, destroy Heritrix -- has the advantage 
that you use the same interface whether local to the same JVM or remote 
in another instance -- or you can bypass the JMX Agent and invoke 
directly on the Heritrix instance the public methods that JMX itself uses.

Here is list of operations available on JMX API (Its followed by 
available attributes): 
http://crawler.archive.org/xref/org/archive/crawler/Heritrix.html#293.  
Here are the operations being invoked: 
http://crawler.archive.org/xref/org/archive/crawler/Heritrix.html#1998 
(Good for figuring how to bypass JMX Agent).

For illustration, here is how the Heritrix instance is created in webapp 
context: 
http://crawler.archive.org/xref/org/archive/crawler/WebappLifecycle.html.  
If you read the Heritrix code, you'll see that internally we're doing 
the same model.  In this class, its just easier to see whats going on.

St.Ack
